AII IT Playbook v1.0

Architecture & StandardsClean Architecture

Clean Architecture Standards

40 min read

Creating systems that are independent of frameworks, UI, and databases while being highly testable.

Chapter 1

Core Concept

The primary goal of Clean Architecture is the separation of concerns. By keeping the business logic independent of external agencies like databases and UI, we create systems that are easier to maintain and test.

Key Characteristics

  • • Independent of Frameworks: Use frameworks as tools, don't build your logic around them.
  • • Testable: Business rules can be tested without the UI, Database, or any external element.
  • • Independent of UI: Changing the web UI shouldn't require changing the business rules.
  • • Independent of Database: Switch from SQL Server to MongoDB with minimal impact on logic.
Domain
Inward Dependency Rule
Chapter 2

Layer Responsibilities

Standardized definition of what goes into each architectural layer.

Entities (Domain)

Value Objects
Aggregates
Domain Services
Domain Events

Business objects and enterprise-wide rules. No dependencies on anything else.

Use Cases (Application)

Command/Query Handlers
DTOs
Mappers
Ports/Interfaces

Application-specific business rules. Orchestrates flow of data to and from entities.

Interface Adapters

Controllers
Presenters
Repository Implementations
Gateways

Converts data between use cases and external formats.

Frameworks & Drivers

Database (EF Core/JPA)
HTTP Client
File System
External APIs

External tools like DB, UI, Devices, Frameworks.

Chapter 3

The Dependency Rule

Source code dependencies can only point inwards. Nothing in an inner circle can know anything at all about something in an outer circle.

How to Invert Dependencies

If the Application layer needs to save data (an Infrastructure concern), it defines an Interface (Port). The Infrastructure layer then Implements (Adapter) that interface.

Domain Knows No One
App Knows Domain
Infra Knows App
typescriptImplementing Dependency Inversion
// --- Application Layer (Inner) ---
export interface IOrderRepository {
  save(order: Order): Promise<void>;
}

export class CreateOrderUseCase {
  constructor(private repo: IOrderRepository) {}
  
  async execute(order: Order) {
    // Business logic...
    await this.repo.save(order);
  }
}

// --- Infrastructure Layer (Outer) ---
export class PostgresOrderRepository implements IOrderRepository {
  async save(order: Order) {
    // Direct database access code
  }
}
Chapter 4

Hexagonal (Ports & Adapters)

Separating the application core from the drivers and driven actors.

Ports & Adapters

Ports: Interfaces that provide entry points to or exits from the application core.

Adapters: Bridges between external technologies and the application's ports.

Driving (Input)

UIs, CLI, Test Scripts

Driven (Output)

DBs, MQ, Mail, SMS

ADAPTER -> [PORT | CORE | PORT] -> ADAPTER
REST API
DOMAIN
PostgreSQL
Chapter 5

Onion Architecture

Emphasizing the domain at the center with concentric rings of abstraction.

Center
Domain Model

Pure business entities and value objects.

Inner Ring
Domain Services

Logic that doesn't belong to a single entity.

Middle Ring
App Services

Orchestration and workflow logic.

Outer Ring
Infra/UI

External technical implementations.

Chapter 6

Practical Implementation

Choosing the right approach based on project complexity.

FactorClean ArchitectureVertical Slice
Domain ComplexityHigh (Rich Domain)Low/Medium (CRUD)
CouplingDecoupled by LayersCoupled by Feature
MaintenanceLong term, EnterpriseFast delivery, Small apps

Standard Folder Structure

src/
core/
domain/
# Entities, Value Objects, Repository Interfaces
application/
# Use Cases, DTOs, Handlers
infrastructure/
# DB Context, Repository Impls, External Clients
webapi/
# Controllers, Routes, Middlewares
Chapter 7

Testing the Layers

Clean Architecture makes testing easier by providing clear boundaries to mock or stub.

Domain Unit Tests
Pure Logic

Test business rules in entities. No infrastructure needed.

Application Unit Tests
Mocked Ports

Test use cases by mocking repository interfaces.

Infrastructure Integration
Real DB/Adapter

Test that adapters correctly interact with external systems.
